texts.orig: /2017/05/24/enable-apparmor-on-a-debian-jessie-cloud-image/

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I merged some  initial Debian support  into the openstack-ansible-security role and ran into an issue enabling AppArmor. The
texts.text: I merged some  initial Debian support  into the openstack-ansible-security role and ran into an issue enabling AppArmor. The

texts.label: code
texts.orig: apparmor
texts.text: apparmor

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: service failed to start and I found this output in the system journal:
texts.text: service failed to start and I found this output in the system journal:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: kernel: AppArmor: AppArmor disabled by boot time parameter
texts.text: kernel: AppArmor: AppArmor disabled by boot time parameter

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Digging in
texts.text: Digging in

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: That was unexpected. I was using the  Debian jessie cloud image  and it uses extlinux as the bootloader. The file didn't reference AppArmor at all:
texts.text: That was unexpected. I was using the  Debian jessie cloud image  and it uses extlinux as the bootloader. The file didn't reference AppArmor at all:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# cat /boot/extlinux/extlinux.conf
default linux
timeout 1
label linux
kernel boot/vmlinuz-3.16.0-4-amd64
append initrd=boot/initrd.img-3.16.0-4-amd64 root=/dev/vda1 console=tty0 console=ttyS0,115200 ro quiet
texts.text:
# cat /boot/extlinux/extlinux.conf
default linux
timeout 1
label linux
kernel boot/vmlinuz-3.16.0-4-amd64
append initrd=boot/initrd.img-3.16.0-4-amd64 root=/dev/vda1 console=tty0 console=ttyS0,115200 ro quiet

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I  learned  that AppArmor is  disabled by default  in Debian unless you  explicitly enable it . In contrast, SELinux is enabled unless you turn it off. To make matters worse, Debian's cloud image doesn't have any facilities or scripts to automatically update the extlinux configuration file when new kernels are installed.
texts.text: I  learned  that AppArmor is  disabled by default  in Debian unless you  explicitly enable it . In contrast, SELinux is enabled unless you turn it off. To make matters worse, Debian's cloud image doesn't have any facilities or scripts to automatically update the extlinux configuration file when new kernels are installed.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Making a repeatable fix
texts.text: Making a repeatable fix

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My two goals here were to:
texts.text: My two goals here were to:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Ensure AppArmor is enabled on the next boot
texts.text: Ensure AppArmor is enabled on the next boot

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Ensure that AppArmor remains enabled when new kernels are installed
texts.text: Ensure that AppArmor remains enabled when new kernels are installed

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The first step is to install grub2:
texts.text: The first step is to install grub2:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: apt-get -y install grub2
texts.text: apt-get -y install grub2

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: During the installation, a package configuration window will appear that asks about where grub should be installed. I selected
texts.text: During the installation, a package configuration window will appear that asks about where grub should be installed. I selected

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /dev/vda
texts.text: /dev/vda

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: from the list and waited for apt to finish the package installation.
texts.text: from the list and waited for apt to finish the package installation.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The next step is to edit
texts.text: The next step is to edit

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /etc/default/grub
texts.text: /etc/default/grub

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: and add in the AppArmor configuration. Adjust the
texts.text: and add in the AppArmor configuration. Adjust the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT
texts.text: GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: line to look like the one below:
texts.text: line to look like the one below:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
GRUB_DEFAULT=0
GRUB_TIMEOUT=5
GRUB_DISTRIBUTOR=`lsb_release -i -s 2> /dev/null || echo Debian`
GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT="quiet apparmor=1 security=apparmor"
GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX=""
texts.text:
GRUB_DEFAULT=0
GRUB_TIMEOUT=5
GRUB_DISTRIBUTOR=`lsb_release -i -s 2> /dev/null || echo Debian`
GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT="quiet apparmor=1 security=apparmor"
GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX=""

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Ensure that the required AppArmor packages are installed:
texts.text: Ensure that the required AppArmor packages are installed:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: apt-get -y install apparmor apparmor-profiles apparmor-utils
texts.text: apt-get -y install apparmor apparmor-profiles apparmor-utils

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Enable the AppArmor service upon reboot:
texts.text: Enable the AppArmor service upon reboot:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: systemctl enable apparmor
texts.text: systemctl enable apparmor

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Run
texts.text: Run

texts.label: code
texts.orig: update-grub
texts.text: update-grub

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: and reboot. After the reboot, run
texts.text: and reboot. After the reboot, run

texts.label: code
texts.orig: apparmor_status
texts.text: apparmor_status

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Final thoughts
texts.text: Final thoughts

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I'm still unsure about why AppArmor is disabled by default. There aren't that many profiles shipped by default (38 on my freshly installed jessie system versus 417 SELinux policies in Fedora 25) and many of them affect services that wouldn't cause significant disruptions on the system.
texts.text: I'm still unsure about why AppArmor is disabled by default. There aren't that many profiles shipped by default (38 on my freshly installed jessie system versus 417 SELinux policies in Fedora 25) and many of them affect services that wouldn't cause significant disruptions on the system.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There is a  discussion that ended last year  around how to automate the AppArmor enablement process when the AppArmor packages are installed. This would be a great first step to make the process easier, but it would probably make more sense to take the step of enabling it by default.
texts.text: There is a  discussion that ended last year  around how to automate the AppArmor enablement process when the AppArmor packages are installed. This would be a great first step to make the process easier, but it would probably make more sense to take the step of enabling it by default.
